text: uh hi everyone I'm Anthony here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Metallica
album 72 Seasons the 11th studio album
from metal Legends Metallica James Lars
Kirk and Robert are back with a thrash
album for the whole family but really
Metallica has long been my favorite act
in all of mainstream metal their early
work so essential to the evolution of
the genre and even commercial Peaks like
The Black Album are fantastic from front
to back and for sure you could
effectively argue there are bands that
are more experimental more technical
more adventurous and proficient but
Metallica has killer grooves and a
thrilling sound and grasped the idea of
anthemic songwriting much better than a
lot of their competition did and I think
that's paid off in an unbreakable Legacy
because while Metallica's catalog does
contain some of the greatest high points
in metal it also has some of the biggest
blunders too like when they angered old
school fans by adopting a more Groove
metal Aesthetics in the mid 90s also cut
their hair we also had the absolutely
awful songs in production Oliver Saint
anger and there's also the record that
people just love to hate that would be
Lulu the creative crossover between
Metallica and the late Lou Reed a
project I respect and even like to a
degree but I can see how this record was
just kind of a non-starter for fans of
each artist but yeah despite some low
points in their catalog Metallica's
place in rock history remains rock hard
and while they've definitely reached a
point where they're almost too big to
fail I think they've kind of gotten out
of the habit of poking the bear as it
were or turning the public against them
whether that be through a crusade
against music downloading or the wave of
hate that comes with the release of a
super super mediocre album and you can
see them making safer decisions in their
PR moves and their output now whether
they're bringing together multiple
corners of the Music World by inviting
everyone to join in on a multi-disc
covers version of The Black Album for
its 30th Anniversary they put out
another Symphony record too and we also
had the very predictable and very
bloated hardwired to self-destruct that
came out in 2016. which was a very low
risk low reward type of project that yes
contained few mistakes but also few
Thrills too it was like the band was
trying to deliver to fans the most
agreeable version of themselves
something that calls back to the
nostalgic commercial peaks of their
sound decades ago but also uproots
anything that would have been genuinely
subversive about their music from that
time and if that's all Metallica was
planning to do with their music from
here on out they could have easily just
made this their last record however I
don't think giving up entirely is
optically speaking very Metallica which
makes marching forward the most most
sensible option to take I guess but what
do you do when you want to drop a new
record but don't want to introduce any
new ideas into the fold you kind of make
the Same album All Over Again of course
except 72 seasons is somehow less
exciting and edgy than its predecessor
failing to even bring a track that's as
Intense or as edgy as the intro from
that album with its profane Hooks and
synced up snares and guitar riffs but
really the big shocker with 72 seasons
is that for such a long album there is
so little to say the riffs and guitar
tones across this record are pretty
heavy and chunky but as far as their
sound they're about as standard as I
think a modern thrash album could get
lars's drums do have a sharp pop to them
the recording on them is pretty good but
his performances aren't exactly
attention grabbing and Kirk hammett's
solos aren't exactly pushing the
envelope either they mostly feel like
him reliving His Glory Days from some of
the band ends most again mainstream
moments in the 90s and maybe what's the
worst quality about some of these tracks
is that the band just doesn't know when
to call it quits the opening title track
here which I do like could have easily
ended after the first solo and following
chorus because the key change and Bridge
and the chorus that comes after that
don't really add that much to the song's
overall excitement or Dynamics it's
weird because the length of this album
and its songs are not really direct or
straightened to the point at all yet the
band isn't really doing anything with
this extra time outside of bringing very
basic changes more courses forgettable
solos and padded out riff passages to be
clear I'm not looking for the band to
cut these songs down to two minutes and
change but there's a reason Lux Eterna
is one of the most Kick-Ass tracks on
this LP too far gone as well have we
forgot we're making a metal album here
where's the urgency or at least the
genuine desire to add some Peaks and
values to these Cuts so that there's
some real drama to them it's a roller
coaster ride the spoken word passage for
example toward the back end of screaming
suicide is so mid it's so unsurprising
it's so unexciting it doesn't really do
anything for the track it's a total
flash goes by in a breeze despite the
fact that this song deals in such a dark
subject matter meanwhile cuts on this
thing that turned down the heat and
turned down the speed are the most
tedious by far you must burn for example
sounds like I'm listening to a less
interesting version of sad but true
there's also the Sinister crown of
barbed wire which doesn't even feature a
memorable song at its core sad as
Metallica is usually pretty good for
some Melodies and some licks that will
stick with you even on some of their
hokiest singles
and
furthermore I'm kind
of I'm kind of balanced and subtler
moments on this project too there's a
lot of run time on this record and most
of the tracks are really just trying to
go Full Throttle hate on the load and
the reload era all you want but I think
a song on the level or uh in the
attitude of a cut like until it sleeps
for example would have done a lot for
just kind of adding to the overall Vibe
of this track list because as it is it's
just super one-dimensional and it stinks
because James Hetfield's voice really
tends to shine in these more low-key
moments and we're being robbed of that
because miraculously still in this era
of Metallica's career his signal voice
sounds amazing if there's anything that
really truly comes across as kick ass in
Metallica's music even on their 11th
record here it's that because James's
passion and ferocity it's carrying a lot
of these tracks frankly even when he's
bringing so so word Salad lyrics and
rhyming criticized scrutinize summarize
patronize his performance on if Darkness
had a son is absolutely bestial even
though the tune to this one isn't even
that good but yeah there's very little
mellow James on this thing outside of a
few spare build up moments on the
lengthy 11 minute closing track which I
mean given what I've said about long
songs on this record earlier yeah this
one's a bit drab and Bloated too even if
there are a few show-stopping moments
along its run time but we shouldn't need
to expend all of these seconds and
minutes just to get uh some fantastic
colorful blazing harmonized guitar solos
but yeah this Metallica record it's very
predictable it's very middle of the road
it's very much the band resting on its
Laurels not doing anything exciting new
subtle really kind of flushing their
versatility down the toilet as well I
mean in this records defense there are a
few standouts a few highlights and the
vast majority of what is here is
listenable but is it re-listenable and
is it anything you would opt to put on
over any of the band's classic albums
not really feeling a strong four to a
light five on this project transition
